newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Woodside says Cossack rig to resume.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Woodside says Cossack rig to resume.

text.p: Woodside Petroleum Ltd said on Friday that it expected production at its Cossack oil platform to resume over the weekend.
Production at the platform was suspended on December 31 and the rig set loose to escape the path of a cyclone.
Woodside spokesman Graham Atherton said the Cossack-Pioneer offshore platform was back at its location but heavy seas had so far prevented its reconnection.
"The seas are abating and we're hoping to reconnect this afternoon," Atherton said.
"In which case they would resume production over the weekend and have a shipment on Monday."
The platform had been producing at a rate of around 90,000 to 95,000 barrels per day (bpd) when it was unhooked.
That production rate is below maximum capacity of 115,000 bpd due to limitations placed on the rig's flaring system.

The platform, which pumps crude oil and gas from the Wanaea and Cossack fields on the North West Shelf, has been plagued by weather-related and technical problems since it was commissioned in November last year.

Equal partners in the North West Shelf are units of The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd, The British Petroleum Co Plc, Japan Australia LNG (MiMi) Pty Ltd, a partnership of Mitsui & Co Ltd and Mitsubishi Corp, Chevron Corp, Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Woodside.
